text: Has anyone figured out an INTERESTING way to build chulane that isn’t just raw value
Combo
Eldrazi Tribal? :3
Huh
Neat
Group hug. Imagine bouncing and replaying [[tempting wurm]] over and over

text: I am shocked you didn't say chaos
Bant is group hug! Everything else is chaos! Weve been over this!
Actually I want to make a 5c group hug now that black has more group hug support recently
Uuuugggghhhh
"hug support" was the name of my band in college
But I just did sultai group hug with volrath
Lol
Group hug is just another type of chaos.
Change my mind...
That's the most common way to build hug.
Kruphix is hug control. And there's hug combo, too
I played chaos with a new person and then group hug. They supperrr hate chaos. Looooove hug
I'm not sure I buy that there's such a thing

Hug to me has a really specific definition; you're giving people things with the hope they can't do math and won't attack you. But just giving people things doesn't make a deck hug. When I Beast Within your creature I'm giving you a thing, but that's not the point. The point is to destroy your thing, and the beast is the downside. You're still breaking parity to give yourself the edge. That's why I'm not sure I really buy hug control or hug combo. Those tend to be just big Beast Within decks where it's not about giving people things to generate goodwill but instead giving people things while you get way more. It's a parity break, not a hug.
With people who don't know how Kruphix rolls, the hugs definitely deflect aggro in the early/mid game

Dana’s not usually wrong

But when he is 

It’s about group hug :stuck_out_tongue_closed_eyes:
So, I am at least partly using classic hug logic/strategy
I've seen Joey's "hug" deck and that's a perfect example though. It's not a Howling Mine, it's a Beast Within
The deflection sometimes even works with people who _should_ know better. Just because they need the resources I give
(I have howling mine effects in there)
I'm not sure being desperate and taking advantage of what is offered is remotely a hug effect either.
When the choice is take the Tempt or lose, you take the tempt. That's also not a hug.
Yeah, I cut Tempt. Too risky
Putting people into those positions is the art of the hug
That's how ineffective hugs is; y'all have to contort the definition in absurd ways to pretend things that aren't hug are hug so you can say it works
Anyone wanna review a deck for tomorrow?
I’m not the one playing with the definition here, that’s you bro
I'm playing Kadena for our stream tomorrow and I took the stock list and tried to beef it up. <https://deckstats.net/decks/101606/1426242-seth-cross-cmdrol-kadena>

text: "I'm running Howling Mine in Nekusar! Hugs!"
First of all, group slug is a thing
And no Joey, hug originally had a pretty clear definition, and a parity break isn't hug
I made 23 spots just taking stuff out and 2 of the lands to come down to 38 and then re-worked the mana base
Sure group slug is, but that's got nothing to do with hug, a concept originally came up with around commanders like Phendalgrif
Sorry, but you guys are contorting what hug is to pretend the deck equivalent of busting up a land with Field of Ruin is a hug effect

“You guys” is separate from “me” cuz I dunno what y’all were talking about before I got here but I never made any assertions about a hug definition. I’d be happy to, though. It’s a diverse strategy. It’s almost like things exist on a spectrum. You can have different flavors of artifact decks and landfall and you can have different flavors of hug.

Hug to me is just fun because itll steroid decks to go off faster then they ever would naturally. Even if the player thinks I'm up to something, they have to decide wasting their turn killing me, the hug player... or killing off the person now also insanely ramped up and likely to kill them next turn XD
Sometimes I just don't care about winning as much as seeing something crazy happen. So I play hug decks then.
Sorry man, just not buying that everything is hug just because calling it that is convenient.
THAT is when hug works, when you just wanna see dumb stuff happen
I have zero issue with that
I only take issue with the people who think it's a strategic way to win games
Yeah, sometimes I enjoy edh games just because it can go off into another world. Like chaos, obviously not all the time, but sometimes it's a nice difference, like planechase
Should have told me you like Planeschase at Vegas, we never played :stuck_out_tongue:
Theme and win con are two different things.
Right? I brought mine too and curse of karona and never played it

Because it's only a strategic way to win games when you're playing with people in danger of choking to death on their own dice, and at that point just dropping shiny objects is probably and effective strategy to win games
I really feel like there’s a straw man you’re aiming at that’s somewhere far afield. When I was in Kansas City I indeed did win games playing Hug. Against your cohost, in fact.
An aristocrats deck doesn't win because you're sacrificing stuff. It wins because sacrificing stuff enables the win con.
I didn't see it, but I don't believe it :slightly_smiling_face: I think you played a parity breaking deck you're calling hug
God dammit, Angelo...
Don't you emote on me
My deck is straight group ramp. Help everyone get as many lands as possible
The. I mind grind

And I think I played a measured game where I analyzed what everyone else was doing and then assumed the role of littlefinger to help people do my bidding. And that wasn’t because they were stupid. It wasn’t because I built up a strong opponent and asked for help tearing them down. I have a control style of hug deck just like some people have aristocrats styles of control decks and some people have Sphinx control decks. 

I even said to you in KC that when I won that game, you wouldn’t accept it because you’d assume the people I played with were bad, but if I’d lost that game, you’d have said “of course you did, you have your enemies resources because hug is a bad strategy.” There’s no winning under the confines of the definitions you’ve decided must exist for this classification if deck you’ve never played before. 

I can’t look at someone’s aristocrats deck and say “oh you don’t have enough blood artist effects so this isn’t really aristocrats.” Not unless the number they’re playing is like actually 0. Like I said before, it’s a spectrum, not a binary. If you’re using a strictly binary system for evaluating deck theme then you’re denying quite a lot of deckbuilding freedom. 

So yeah my deck breaks parity. It also helps other people. I’m political when I play it, does that mean it’s not hug and that it’s a politics deck? Well my Mimeoplasm deck has some spells cast cast spells from the graveyard instead of just creatures, does that mean it’s not actually reanimator? These things have a texture to them and it’s diminutive to ignore that. Not because you’re stepping on my precious definitions, but because I think it’ll actually get in the way of you trying to beat me.
You yourself just explained you understand my definitions, that they're clear and not shifting, and yours doesn't qualify

A hug deck is one designed to give people things with the hope that politically it will generate a reaction that will hopefully help you live longer, or just do stupid things. Anything where you're giving people something but you get way more isn't hug, it's a parity break, and if I accept that is hug than I have to accept all kinds of cards are hug cards, and I'm just not gonna accept that Beast Within is a hug card.
Or Vaevictus the Dire, etc.
<@U4V5EHQ2G> I think you're making a distinction without a difference.

The function of a definition isn’t to be restrictive and all-encompassing. There are different types of political favors to curry in game, but it would be reductive for me to say one style of favor is less political than another. See also the definition of queer. It’s a bigger umbrella than many of the other things that fall within it. 

Also, it depends how you use things. So beast within may not be a hug card, but it is a card you’ll use in hug.
I don't think so. I think hug had a very clear definition, and a lot of people want to change that to claim their not remotely hug deck is a hug deck.

when the theme pages are made, each deck has a score of how much it  follows each theme, then the highest proportional result is returned. BUT the final result does not negate the presence of other themes that are present but not as concentrated, it just doesn't currently show them.
so a deck can have a "hug package" along with other packages as well
And what would a hug package consist of in a deck?
checking text of each card, looking for those strings
so it's more a per-card determination, then a package would be a bunch of those applicable cards

Hug is just this weird thing where people want to pretend a bunch of not remotely hug things are hug. Nobody claims their deck is a mill variant under the umbrella of mill when they run three cards that put cards in the yard as part of their reanimation deck, because a mill deck has a specific meaning, but people want to jam in a Howling Mine and call their deck hug
Does that mean that each deck that breaks parity is a hug deck? I think that's a bit of an arbitrary line to draw. Decks of all different archetypes seek to break parity.
Vaevictis is not hugs, but he seeks to break parity.
howling mine makes a deck more hug than it was, but unless there are other hug cards present, then hug won't likely be the main theme
Stax decks seek to break parity.
Prison/lock decks seek to break parity.
I think a bunch of people have redefined hug to mean what they want it to mean vs what it originally meant. That's fine I guess, but I'm not particularly interested in participating.
Breaking parity is not an archetype.
It's a strategic element.
Sure, but not every deck is necessarily an archetype either
Though I guess not being archetypal is maybe in it's own way an archetype
Goodstuff is a term after all
So.... My deck that runs a ton of group beneficial decks has to be an archetype-less deck because it breaks parity, and therefore cannot be called hug in the remotest sense.

Hug is one of if not *the* only archetype that is wholly unique to multiplayer magic. It really shouldn't be a surprise that it has a morphing definition.

"What hug originally meant" is also just not how language or this game works. As the game evolves so do the decks and so does the definition. If you're clinging to a single idea - that to be PROPER hug i have to give other people more than I gave myself - then you're ignoring a big chunk of strategical implication
I'm mostly just saying that just because your deck gives stuff to people it isn't a hug deck. Some people want to say it is a hug deck. That's fine, and apparently we're gonna disagree there.
I've got a very honed theme of benefiting the group. If you want to call that goodstuff, I suppose that's your prerogative
Sure but if I accept that Joey than I accept Beast Within is a hug card. Not interested.
Beast Within doesn't benefit the whole group
It's no more a hug card than Polymorph

I'm also not going to say that every deck who gives something to someone else is a hugs deck. Just like I'm not gonna say a deck with two blood artist effects is automatically aristocrats and just because you have ten artifacts doesn't mean you're playing an artifact deck. what matters is density, strategy, synergy, how you use the cards in game, and a lot of subtlety that narrow definitions would otherwise erase.
once again, Beast Within is not a hug card, but it is a card hug will use.
who is saying beast within is a hug card?
dana is trying to force my definition and it's frustrating
And you mine

If everything that remotely gives away a thing is a hug deck, then almost everything is a hug deck, and the term has no meaning. If people want to do that just so they can claim they play hugs, I'm not gonna stop them.
And that's not been my definition ever.
like literally ever in this conversation
So what is your definition

I know mine, and I can clearly define it, and point to the original commander in Phendalgrif, and define what the end point of the game is; to just either just see dumb stuff happen via giving out things, or to hopefully convince everyone that you giving things out is helpful to them (it rarely is) long enough for you to pull off some manner of win. The former is a variant on chaos, and the latter often relies on people not understanding resources in multi-player games or being blinded by their own greed, both of which certainly can happen.
I think it’s time to move to <#CHA8U3W1H|hot-and-heavy>, or take a couple minutes, people.
I think once I accept decks built around you get 1 but I get 3 kinds of parity breaking things as hug then that opens up nearly everything as hug
<@U4V5EHQ2G> how do you define Sliver tribal?
Whats the definition of definition these days anyways
A deck built predominately around slivers as your creatures, where sometimes you mix in non-slivers if you're a hack.
Does that definition include a win con, or even why you're including Slivers?
Or even a strategy.
That's a good point though, because for example there was that one Game Knights where Jimmy ran his dragon tribal deck and cast like 5 non-dragons for every 1 dragon.
Is your Glissa deathtouch tribal deck just a goodstuff deck because "deathtouch" is neither a tribe nor an archetype?
By the original definition if tribal, your deck cannot rightly be called tribal.
Unless language and definitions evolve.
At this point since we're accepting anying as hug then sure, my Glissa deathtouch deck is avatar tribal.

My contention is that it's *complicated*. which right off the bat probably means you may think it's invalid because it's not clear or concise, but as I said ten minutes ago, the function of a definition is not always to be all-encompassing and finite. Look up the 40 definitions of the word 'set'. That's also not clear. "Queer" is not clear. It grows and expands and shrinks and breathes and this card game does that too.

So yeah some decks give people things. Some use politics. Some are chaotic. Some break parity *because that's how you win games of magic*. Some use the monarch and some use minds' dilation. Some even use the graveyard.

But blinding people by their own greed is exactly how I win games of magic and exactly how I beat Max. I don't think you think Max is "choking on pennies" or however you put it earlier, and yet I still beat him. So either he's bad at magic or I'm not actually playing hug? That's a narrow mindset and it's not useful. Sorry that this isn't a clinical and sterile facts-only situation but themes are a matter of what feels right rather than strict and dependent inclusion of specific cards. I've said four times now that it's a spectrum, that it has gradience and texture.
I remember the game knights when the professor played a “nekusar deck” that was actually Yidris in the command zone and he never even found any wheels
I submit that any deck archetype definition that includes why is too restrictive.
It's absolutely complicated, and a lot of it is on a sliding scale for an individual. Clearly a dragon tribal deck can have like four dragons in it if you're on Game Knights.
That was my last point. I'm gonna listen to music and sort cards for a sell list now.
I'm not gonna consider that a dragon tribal deck, and Jimmy clearly does. We're gonna have to agree to disagree.

I get that you want people to be honest with themselves about what their deck is actually doing. But if you're looking for a narrow or clear or concise definition for every aspect of this game, you won't always find it.
Perhaps a better group hug definition definition is "a deck that strategically provides positive benefits in order to influence how others play the game"
Although that has a why in it

I didn't say I have to have real hard and delineated categories or anything. I don't sit down and ask people what their deck archetype is or anything, nor do I argue when they're running Con Sphinx and Sun Titan in their merfolk deck.
Is this what it's like to be a kid and see your parents have an argument and get excited because you're going to get 2 Christmas's moving forward?
Wait, this is exactly what that was like...all those years ago
Not only that but they compete over giving you the better christmas
It's win/win/win!
It seems like you apply the opposite metric, though - when a card gives someone else something, you assume that we think it's a hug card. We don't.
But I also think most K&T decks I've seen have way more in common with Selvala 1.0 than they do Phendalgrif
Trust me, I don't assume people Beast Within'ing my stuff think they're hugging me.
those can all be different variations of hug :stuck_out_tongue:
in the 30 years since pheldagriff was printed, the archetyope has evolved and expanded
And your definitions for that are way closer to Jimmy and tribal than mine. So be it.
A deck that strategically gives net benefits to opponents.

You are doing a lot of arguing from a position where you think you're being open-minded about the definition of hug while simultaneously being pretty closed minded about even considering an alternate opinion on it though Joey.
How is that as a definition?
talk like that we better move to H&H bro
lol

attachments.fallback: Someone sent a GIF in #brews using Tenor

text: :thinking_face::thinking_face::thinking_face:

I always come back to Selvala ER for this. It's a deck giving cards, but there's no attempt to be political or change anyone's mind. You're giving cards is entirely so you can get more, and more mana, and dig down further and faster to your win condition. It's not remotely hug based. The giving of cards is entirely incidental. Edric falls in the same catagory, and something like K&T and a lot of the supposed hug control, etc decks seem way closer to that kind of deck. If someone wants to call that hugs then okay, whatever, but I'm personally not convinced.

Just going to throw this out amidst everything, but there is a deck in Modern that plays a ton of howling mine effects in order maximize it's own chances of chaining extra turn spells. It's using hug effects but still trying to do it's own thing. The reason it seems to not do well is because it turns out giving your opponents(in modern at least) isn't a good idea no matter how many extra turns you take. I don't think hug as an archetype is 100% unique to multiplayer/commander since the "taking turns" deck at it's heart is a hug deck, only that it's named after the means it which it wins like everything else. Scapeshift tells you what deck it is, but really it's a ramp combo deck etc. Not that I don't agree/disagree with the conversation at large, just wanted to nitpick that point.

Anyways, back to how you were Mom and Dad!

So Dana, would you say that Hug decks are bad because they shouldn't give other people resources or because they aren't able to use the resources that everyone gets better than the 3 opposing players combined?
Whether an archetype is good or bad is a separate issue.

And here's a fair point; some archetypal names are way more open-ended than others in what they do. Control is super vague and open. There's a ton of decks one could reasonably describe as control, and they may look really, really different. Enchantress is much more narrow in that there's a lot less variance among the decks one could describe as enchantress.
So Joey considers hug as a label to be like control, and I consider it to be like enchantress.
That doesn't mean he's necessarily wrong in that regard. Doesn't mean I am either. It also doesn't mean I have to agree with how he views the label, nor he me.

<@U33EGB4TX> I think they're fine at just creating wonky game states via throwing resources at everyone. If that's your end goal, then they pretty consistently do that. If your end goal is to politically manipulate people into thinking they're getting a great deal when they're in fact not, I'm not sure they're very effective unless you're playing terrible opponents.
And if you're getting disproportionate resources or ones you can use better than everyone else, it's not (to me) a hugs deck, because Selvala and Edric arn't hugs decks.

I agree with the last part in theory. It's a common mindset to hit the hug player first, for good reason. As mentioned before though, it's not always black and white because now you're stuck deciding to either hit the hug player (what you want to do) or the other people ramping as well, who should be huge threats themselves
That said selvala and edric are so good at what they do for the person playing, everyone knows (or should know) to hit them without question >.>

So maybe is it that it's more dependent on the skill of the hug player than the other 3 at the table? Maybe it's a case of you have to count on being the better player compared to the other players at the table than it is hoping the other players are the equivalent of Affliction Warlocks in WoW. If you can time everything right and put everything off just long enough I so the other players don't get enough of those hug resources compared to your payoff I think that sounds like a more typical scenario than "You shouldn't attack me! I gave you THINGS!"
That sounds way closer to Selvala though
Than Peldagriff or something
Or Pheldagriff players are notoriously bad? The only time I played against a Pheldagriff deck the guy won by giving infinite tokens to every player with a [[suture priest]] in play

attachments.fallback: Suture Priest {1}{W} // Creature — Cleric // Whenever another creature enters the battlefield under your control, you may gain 1 life. // Whenever a creature enters the battlefield under an opponent's control, you may have that player lose 1 life. // 1/1
attachments.text:
Creature — Cleric
Whenever another creature enters the battlefield under your control, you may gain 1 life.
Whenever a creature enters the battlefield under an opponent's control, you may have that player lose 1 life.
*1/1*
attachments.title: Suture Priest {1}{W}

text: It's the OG hug commander
Just an easy one to cite

It gets difficult with say Selvala or edric because you know they can go off, but that darn Omnath that just got an extra card or land is about to 1 shot... so what do you do? 
Group hug players hope and will try and politics the omnath threat, and end up on top usually. 

I think that scenario is a fair way to play... but its suuuupppeeer unstable lol. Just gambling at that point
But yeah... never played against a hippo deck that could cause a situation like the above
Best you can so is give everyone 20 lands and then use that x/x pump spell based on lands to one shot someone with a hippo
At least that Pheldagriff player had a wincon....

The Selvala and Edric thing going off though is kind of an interesting point. They're not hug decks because people understand the resources granted swing wildly into the pilot's favor, but people maybe don't get that about K&T (yet, maybe that changes) so it is hug. So in some cases then the argument would be the difference between hug, and not how the person accross the table is assessing threat.
There are wide token decks and there are tall token decks. Are either of them less tokeny because they approach the game differently?
No?
<@U4V5EHQ2G> let me start here: what is your assertion?
That just because your deck gives things out it isn't necessarily a hug deck.
Granted.
I think I can agree with that.
Not that anyone is arguing that specifically.
But simply the act of a deck giving things to an opponent isn't enough for it to be a hug deck. For me, specifically, if you giving things out disproportionately benefits you, it's not hugs.
Why not?

It's why I mentioned Beast Within as an example. Again, not that anyone is arguing it's a hugs card, but it's a single card to use a representative of a deck. As a card, it's disproportionately helping you. The give away part is incidental.
Agreed: Beast Within is not a hug card.
What about Temple Bell?
Temple Bell would be, outside say Nekusar or something.
It's also a good example of why hugs doesn't work, but that's another argument.
Okay; what about Tempt With Whatever?
Disregarding whether or not the card is good.
That's a separate discussion.
Generally not intended to hug
You're getting disproportionate advantage.
And that's where you primarily see them, the green one in a landfall deck, red one in Angry Omnath or Purpuros, etc.
They're Beast Within cards
Not entirely.
Your opponent getting stuff is kind of incidental to you getting more.
With Beast Within, you're taking something away.
I mean, swap Field of Ruin in there then
With Tempt With, you're only giving something to them.
Are you going somewhere with this?
Yes.
Both of those examples, you're taking something of higher value and giving something of lesser value.
Tempt With, you're only giving.
To get higher value
There's a distinction but the end result is the same
You're getting more, yes, but your opponents haven't lost anything tangible.
Those cards seem to me to be more of a stax variant where you're trying to break parity, but one where you give your opponent choices and enticements.
Hold on, I need to drive somewhere
It's kind of an inverted stax

Not gonna lie, I skipped the majority of this conversation,  but I will say that I think Dana's hugs definition is fundamentally inaccurate.

The idea of Group Hug is to utilize symmetrical effects in a way where they benefit you the most. You then add in some asymmetrical effects that can help you or an opponent and use politics to even out the table against the strongest player of the moment until you can win.
"Giving people stuff and hoping" is not a strategy.
So since the Hug conversation moved to HnH :sweat_smile: Anyone wanna look at that Kadena list?
Yeah, noticed that after I commented.
To make the list farther down: <https://deckstats.net/decks/101606/1426242-seth-cross-cmdrol-kadena>

text: AND ANOTHER THING
I CANT BELIEVE YOU WOULD SAY THAT GROUP HUG IS
Nah I’m messin
<@UEF135G05> I'm taking it even a step further: trying to define an archetype by strategy is restrictive and unnecessary.

The original use was in Pheldagrif, which was almost always used either politically (which I argue doesn't work) or for just silliness. If someone wants to argue that definition has broadened then fine. You're welcome to be Jimmy and say you're playing dragon tribal.
I don't agree, and that's okay.
BOY THAT WAS CONTENTIOUS NOW LET'S TALK ABOUT SETTLE THE WRECKAGE!
It's a solid card I can never find a slot for
You can Sunforge for it
Don't currently have a Forger deck but yeah, that helps in boros.
In Jeskai I think I'd just rather run Aetherize
Yeah, and even Aetherize doesn’t usually make the cut in the wake of Wrath of God, Austere Command, Blasphemous Act, Supreme Verdict, and Time Wild :weary:
I like Settle in decks that would play Dusk//Dawn and Retribution of the Meek

If you’re in blue I actually like aetherspouts more than aetherize. Making them redraw their threats or terminus-ing them is better than sometimes making them discard to the yard and let Joey mages do Joey mage things.
And the obligatory “just replay them out” but too
[[settle the wreckage]]

text: Denying draw is huge, it's why Noxious Revial is an absolute backbreaker in some formats, same with Jace's Fateseal.
Things I only recently learned: Fateseal is named after the Mirage card [[sealed fate]]

attachments.fallback: Sealed Fate {X}{U}{B} // Sorcery // Look at the top X cards of target opponent's library. Exile one of those cards and put the rest back on top of that player's library in any order.
attachments.text:
Sorcery
Look at the top X cards of target opponent's library. Exile one of those cards and put the rest back on top of that player's library in any order.
_It's good to know more about your enemy's fate than your enemy does._

text: I had no idea
